turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: No, that -- that's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)
with administrative agencies.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: That's true.
It certainly can't -- it can't rest on a mere presumption.
But I -- I do think that after the Government has shown a type of membership which given -- giving the -- the administrators the -- the right to make a reasonable inferences --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: After he'd shown enough to show that he's a kind of membership that justifies exclusion then, of course, the burden is met.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- is that what you mean?

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Well, I -- I don't really think that the -- the Government has the task of negating every possible defense that could be raised either --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Certainly.

I'm not talking about defense but does it have the duty or the burden of showing that he come to -- within the class that can be deported or excluded by reason of the existence of the facts they attempted to establish.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about other separate defenses or --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As I understand it, you say that membership, according to the regulations on the Act, is not enough.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Bare membership.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's right.
All right.
And -- and he --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Membership with -- without any -- any other evidence whatsoever are inferences which could be drawn from evidence to show --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That -- that he's not a mere nominal member.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: That he -- that he is -- there could -- that he's -- that he's not a mere nominal member.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That if the --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: Well, do you -- do you say that if the only proof before the examiner was that this man was what -- what used to be called a card-carrying Communist, would that be -- not be enough?

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Well, perhaps, there are many circumstances where --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: -- where --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: -- there was no evidence at all except proof on that part was issued to him and he became a member as a card-carrying Communist, there's nothing else.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: I'm -- I'm not sure whether in -- under the circumstances that that case -- I think it could perhaps be shown that the Communist Party doesn't accept persons willy-nilly in certain periods more than others.
But it -- it does discriminate and if it were shown, if there were something on that record to show that -- that he didn't drift into the party as --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: -- an idle joiner --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: -- there's nothing except the issuance to him when he became a member of the Communist Party, nothing else, then what would be your position?

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Well, I -- I don't --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: I -- I can't really state that.
I don't think the case has come up.
It -- certainly -- I -- I think in the Kessler versus Strecker case, there was evidence there that a -- that Strecker joined the Party and then failed to pay dues.
All there was in that case was a card.
And I think Strecker produced some evidence to the effect that under the rules of the Communist Party, person who doesn't his dues for four months is dropped, automatically dropped.
And the Court felt that under those circumstances that mere fact that he had a --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Card.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: -- a card wasn't sufficient.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Imlay, before you sit down, we, lawyers, have been trying to be accurate in different language but I got the impression, you correct me if I'm wrong, that except in the matter of phrasing, there wasn't any difference between you and Mr. Justice Black in his interrogatory to you about burden of proof because I got what you said, which is why I am asking questions, you would disagree with him that when the record is all in, it's the Government's task to establish that he was "a member".

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm -- you used the word "probative value".

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In other words, if the Government must make out its case --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- in determining whether it has made it out (Inaudible) differ of course.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it's the Government's job to make out its case that this fellow is a member in the particular offense in which that term is used in that statute with the content that must be given to it considering the kind of a statute it is.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you agree with that?

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: That's correct with one caveat and that is, of course, the term "burden of proof".
It's -- it's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I didn't use that.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes, it's a judicial term.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't use that.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: And -- yes.
I -- I think the -- the administrators, the -- the Board of Immigration Appeals looks at the whole evidence.
And if it doesn't find the evidence there, why, I -- I think that it -- it wouldn't be warranted in -- in affirming an administrative appeal certainly.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And for instance you just had -- "Yes, I joined the Communist Party if," there's one -- another question is put to you, "I joined the Communist Party if," and that's all the Government has.
One -- a real question would be raised whether the Government has made out his case.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes, it -- it certainly would.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I don't see why you say that.
Statute says, "join the Communist Party", and -- except for the definition of the -- the regulation as it relates to joining it for food and so forth, joining, it seems to me, means joining.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes, I -- I think that the Galvan case said that --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You're -- I think you're -- I -- I think you failed to argue the point that's really the bottom of this case whether you can justify this application to the statute constitutional.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.
In -- in that regard --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: -- Mr. Justice Harlan, as we've stated in our -- our brief in this case, all of these questions have been very extensively briefed and argued in the Harisiades and the Galvan case.
I think most of them were met in the Harisiades case.
And of course, the -- the 1950 Act just really extended the -- the policy of the 1940 Act to the Communist Party as such.
And that was the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do you -- do you agree with your opponent that Galvan properly read or requires that there must be some rational connection between the statute and the purpose to export only undesirable aliens?
There must be some rational collection.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.
It couldn't be completely arbitrary.
Of course --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: It isn't fair --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: -- there -- there comes a --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- it isn't fair to read Galvan that way.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do you agree with that?

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes, there -- there comes a point, if -- If legislation were based on mere fantasy or pretense, as this Court stated in Harisiades, you would have a different question.
This -- the policy that appears in Section 22 was based on 19 years of legislative study.
It -- it wasn't based on fantasy or pretense.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, the essence of the constitutional question is to whether it is irrational or rational for Congress to say that a man who is a member of the Communist Party, as in this case, in 1935 is an undesirable alien.
That's the essence of the question, isn't it?

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: That's the question, yes.
We think that was decided in the account --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That isn't the question.
The question is whether Communist can constitutionally exercise that power --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- not whether it's rationally say that is true.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Well, that's true.
We've -- this Court has -- has never --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: -- that's -- that's a valid correction because this Court has never questioned the wisdom of Congress in this field which is considered a -- primarily a field for political action rather than action of the more usual types.
This field -- this particular exercise of power is intertwined with the power to maintain a republican form of government and national security, and it often is -- is exercised under the war power.
And as I say and as Galvan points out Harisiades unless, at least, the congressional policy is totally irrational based on -- on considerations which no reasonable man would consider valid.

The deportation of Jews and Catholics, I think, was pointed out in yesterday's discussion as perhaps an example of such a policy unless that appears why this Court has usually differed to the judgment, the wisdom of Congress in this field no matter how unjust, harsh or -- harsh it -- the -- or how much of a hardship it produces on the individual alien in its administration.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Before (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- whether why you so readily agreed when you were asked whether the statute says "join" and that's joining Communist Party.
The statute doesn't say that, the statute says members.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Therefore, we have to construe (Inaudible) members of affiliated (Inaudible) in the context of this statute.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that's not a mathematical term.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: No, it isn't.

turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Imlay.

turn.speaker: carl_h_imlay
turn.label: Mr. Carl H. Imlay
turn.text: Thank you.
